unnormalised: Hey folks! Ever feel like you're drowning in a sea of tech jargon? Especially when browsing the internet? Today, let's decode some common internet terms that even your grandma might be hearing about. Don't worry, we'll keep it simple, no need for a PhD in Computer Science!
normalised: Hey folks! Ever feel like you're drowning in a sea of tech jargon? Especially when browsing the internet? Today, let's decode some common internet terms that even your grandma might be hearing about. Don't worry, we'll keep it simple, no need for a P-H-D in Computer Science!

unnormalised: First up, let's tackle "WiFi". Everyone uses it, right? But did you know that "WiFi" isn't actually an abbreviation for anything official? It's just a catchy name! You connect to your WiFi router using a password (hopefully a strong one!). These routers usually operate on frequencies like 2.4GHz or 5GHz.
normalised: First up, let's tackle "W-i-F-i". Everyone uses it, right? But did you know that "W-i-F-i" isn't actually an abbreviation for anything official? It's just a catchy name! You connect to your W-i-F-i router using a password (hopefully a strong one!). These routers usually operate on frequencies like two point four G-H-z or five G-H-z.

unnormalised: Then there's "URL". That's the web address, like "www.example.com". Think of it as the address for your favorite online shop, say, "www.amazon.in". You can copy and paste URLs to share links with your friends on WhatsApp. Remember those long, weird URLs? Link shorteners like bit.ly help make them more manageable.
normalised: Then there's "U-R-L". That's the web address, like "double u double u double u dot example dot com". Think of it as the address for your favorite online shop, say, "double u double u double u dot amazon dot in". You can copy and paste U-R-L-s to share links with your friends on WhatsApp. Remember those long, weird U-R-L-s? Link shorteners like bit dot L-Y help make them more manageable.

unnormalised: What about "ISP"? That's your Internet Service Provider. Airtel, Jio, Vodafone Idea - they're all ISPs. They're the ones bringing the internet to your doorstep. You pay them a monthly fee, say Rs. 799 for a specific data plan. Speaking of data, ever heard of "MB" or "GB"? Those are megabytes and gigabytes, units for measuring how much data you’re using.
normalised: What about "I-S-P"? That's your Internet Service Provider. Airtel, Jio, Vodafone Idea - they're all I-S-P-s. They're the ones bringing the internet to your doorstep. You pay them a monthly fee, say rupees seven hundred and ninety nine for a specific data plan. Speaking of data, ever heard of "M-B" or "G-B"? Those are megabytes and gigabytes, units for measuring how much data you’re using.

unnormalised: "HTTP" and "HTTPS" are a bit more technical, but still important. They're the protocols that allow your browser to communicate with the web server. "HTTPS" is the secure version, denoted by the little padlock in your browser's address bar. Always prefer "HTTPS" sites, especially when entering sensitive info like your credit card details. Something like your SBI credit card number.
normalised: "H-T-T-P" and "H-T-T-P-S" are a bit more technical, but still important. They're the protocols that allow your browser to communicate with the web server. "H-T-T-P-S" is the secure version, denoted by the little padlock in your browser's address bar. Always prefer "H-T-T-P-S" sites, especially when entering sensitive info like your credit card details. Something like your S-B-I credit card number.

unnormalised: Next on the list: "VPN"! A Virtual Private Network. It encrypts your internet traffic and hides your IP address, giving you extra privacy. Lots of people use VPNs to access content that might be restricted in their region. Many are available on the Play Store.
normalised: Next on the list: "V-P-N"! A Virtual Private Network. It encrypts your internet traffic and hides your I-P address, giving you extra privacy. Lots of people use V-P-N-s to access content that might be restricted in their region. Many are available on the Play Store.

unnormalised: Let's not forget "cookie" (not the edible kind!). These are small files websites store on your computer to remember your preferences. Cookies can be helpful, but they can also track your browsing activity. You can usually manage your cookie settings in your browser. Clear your cookies every now and then for better privacy, alright?
